data.sample_size: 265,180 students from 10,221 schools across 41 countries (analytic sample after excluding incomplete data)
data.unit_of_analysis: Individual student (nested within schools within countries)
data.notes: Hierarchical/nested data structure; multilevel modeling used. Mathematics ability estimated with five plausible values analyzed separately and then averaged. Multiple constructs measured via self-report Likert scales; mathematics self-concept measured by a 5-item scale (Cronbach’s alpha = 0.88). Significance threshold set at p < .001 due to large N; effect sizes calculated using Tymms’ approach consistent with Cohen’s d to assess substantive importance.

method.description: The study used multilevel modeling on the OECD PISA 2003 dataset to test the Big-Fish-Little-Pond Effect (BFLPE) on mathematics self-concept and examine moderation by socioeconomic status and academic self-regulation constructs. Analyses incorporated student-level ability (linear and quadratic), school-average ability, and interactions with a set of 16 moderators. Five plausible values for mathematics ability were used in separate models and results were averaged. Effect sizes were computed to gauge practical significance.
steps: Obtain PISA 2003 data for 15-year-old students across 41 countries.
Exclude cases with incomplete data to arrive at the analytic sample (N ≈ 265,180).

Compute/confirm measures for SES (parental education, occupation, home resources, cultural possessions) and academic self-regulation constructs (intrinsic/extrinsic motivation, learning strategies including elaboration, memorization, and control strategies, self-efficacy, anxiety, social orientations, sense of belonging, student-teacher relations, and positive student interactions).
Measure mathematics self-concept using the five-item scale (Cronbach’s alpha = 0.88).
Estimate individual mathematics ability using five plausible values; run analyses separately for each plausible value.
Specify three-level multilevel models (students within schools within countries) with fixed and random effects.
Include predictors: individual ability (linear and quadratic), school-average ability (to test BFLPE), moderators, and interaction terms between school-average ability and each moderator.
Fit multilevel regression models for each moderator across the five plausible values; average parameter estimates.
Apply p < .001 threshold for statistical significance and compute effect sizes (Tymms/Cohen’s d) to assess substantive significance.
Interpret main effects and interactions, emphasizing effect sizes and robustness/generalizability of the BFLPE.
method.models: Three-level multilevel linear regression models with fixed and random effects at student, school, and country levels; interactions between school-average ability and moderators; parameters averaged across five plausible values of achievement; effect sizes computed per Tymms’ approach consistent with Cohen’s d.
method.independent_variables: Individual mathematics ability (linear and quadratic), school-average ability (BFLPE predictor), SES components (parental education, parental occupation, home/educational resources, cultural possessions), academic self-regulation constructs (intrinsic motivation, extrinsic/instrumental motivation, self-efficacy, anxiety), learning strategies (elaboration, memorization, control strategies), social constructs (cooperative and competitive orientations, student-teacher relations, positive student interactions, sense of belonging).

results.summary: Results confirmed a robust BFLPE: higher school-average ability predicted lower mathematics self-concept after accounting for individual ability, with a substantively meaningful negative effect size. Individual ability positively predicted self-concept (linear and quadratic terms). Many moderators showed statistically significant interactions with school-average ability, but most were small in substantive terms. Memorization strategy and anxiety exacerbated the negative BFLPE, while positive student interactions and student-teacher relations modestly mitigated it. SES showed weak positive associations with self-concept and minimal moderation, supporting the generalizability of the BFLPE across SES levels. Overall, moderation effects were generally small, and the BFLPE was consistent across diverse student characteristics.
